learning_outcomes.description: Explain important anatomical and physiological features of the various major organ systems
Compare and contrast the normal anatomy and physiology of various species including mammals and birds
Relate the anatomy and physiology of these animals to the maintenance of homeostasis
Relate the anatomy and physiology of these animals to their lifestyles and environments
Communicate effectively, using the specialised language of anatomy and physiology.

assessments.weighting: <dd>30% Each sequential item contributes 7.5% towards the sequential practical quiz (total 30%) </dd>
assessments.task_description:
• There will be a practical quiz which you are expected to complete after a set of practicals to ensure that you have read the accompanying material and assess practical learning outcomes.
  • Each quiz will cover a combination of 2 practicals and will use Blackboard as a platform.
  • Practical quizzes will be available from Mondays at 13:00 hours and will be due the following Wednesday at 13:00 hours, on weeks 3, 6, 9 and 12.
  • Quizzes will have a combination of multiple-choice questions and short answer questions.


The practical sessions have been designed to support student learning through the 'hands-on' application of the theory content. Attendance at practicals will assist students with a greater understanding of concepts for completion of the sequential practical quizzes.

If you have any questions about the practicals or the content, please contact the course coordinator via email.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately by including the platform used, prompts used and original text if used as an editor. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions. 


Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online test/quiz. 

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Contact AskUs immediately: support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The practical quiz will open on Monday at 13:00 hours, is completed digitally and submitted to a Blackboard submission link by 13:00 hours of the following Wednsday (48 hours). You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
All lectures and practical activities delivered from week 1 to week 6 (including week 6) will be assessed. The use of personal class notes and slides is permitted.

The examination will be a digital (computer-based, bring your own computer and make sure it is fully charged), invigilated examination, administered in-person during the schedule class session and in the same room as all the lectures. Have your UQ student ID card available for all of your exams.

Loan laptops from teaching staff are not available – should you require a loan laptop, please contact the Library.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
All lectures and practical activities not evaluated in the In-Semester exam will be evaluated (week 7 till week 13). The use of personal class notes and slides is permitted.

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

Students will compare and contrast anatomical and physiological characteristics across multiple livestock species, analysing how differences in system design influence productivity, adaptability, and welfare. A strong focus is placed on homeostasis, exploring how regulatory mechanisms such as thermoregulation, hormonal control, metabolic balance, and fluid regulation support optimal performance in variable environments, including intensive, pasture‑based, and climate‑challenged production settings.


Sub-activity: Week 1 - Axial Skeleton and Muscles Week 2 - Muscles and meat Week 3 - Cell Biology Week 4 - Endocrinology Week 5 - Endocrinology Week 6 - Nervous System Week 8 - Reproductive system Week 9 - Digestive system anatomy Week 10 - Digestive system physiology Week 11 - Cardiovascular System Week 12 - Respiratory System Week 13 - Renal System

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 13(02 Mar - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Practical Series

The course also investigates how anatomical and physiological adaptations shape livestock behaviour, nutritional requirements, reproductive efficiency, and resilience to environmental stressors. Practical sessions and case studies highlight real‑world applications in production animal management, including interpreting physiological data, assessing animal condition, and evaluating factors that influence health and productivity.


Sub-activity: Week 2 - Surface Anatomy Week 3 - Cell microscopy and histology Week 4 - Endocrinology Week 6 - Nervous System - anatomy and histology Week 8 - Reproductive System - anatomy Week 9 - Rumen and monogastric - anatomy Week 11 - Cardio-respiratory System - anatomy and histology week 12 - Renal System - anatomy and histology

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
